case_vignette: A 68-year-old male visits his primary care physician after an episode of syncope during a tennis match. He reports exertional dyspnea with mild substernal chest pain. On physical exam a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard best at the right 2nd intercostal space. This murmur was not heard at the patient's last appointment six months ago.
question: Which  would most support a diagnosis of aortic stenosis?
correct_ans: murmur radiates to carotid arteries bilaterally

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your medical history, specifically related to your heart health.

Have you ever had a heart attack or any other type of cardiac event?

Do you have a family history of heart disease or cardiac problems?

Have you been diagnosed with any heart conditions, such as coronary artery disease or heart failure?
I haven't provided any information about a heart attack, family history of heart disease, or any diagnosed heart conditions before.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some additional questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your shortness of breath and chest pain.

Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as fatigue, weakness, or swelling in your legs?

Have you recently traveled or been exposed to any illnesses or infections?

Do you have a history of smoking or exposure to secondhand smoke?

Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently?
No, I haven't mentioned any other symptoms, recent travel, exposure to illnesses, smoking habits, or changes in appetite or weight.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to perform a physical examination to help determine the cause of your shortness of breath and chest pain.

Can you please remove your shirt and lie on the examination table for me?

I will listen to your lungs with a stethoscope and check your heart rate to see if there are any abnormal sounds or rhythms. I will also check your blood pressure and perform a quick examination of your heart and chest to see if there are any signs of any underlying conditions.

Great, thank you for your cooperation! Spirometry is a test that measures how well your lungs are functioning. It involves blowing air into a device called a spirometer, which measures the volume of air you can exhale and how quickly you can exhale it. This can help us determine if you have any obstructive or restrictive lung diseases, such as COPD or asthma.

I will now prepare the spirometer and explain how the test will be performed. Please sit comfortably and take a deep breath. When I tell you to start blowing, try to blow as hard and fast as you can into the spirometer. Can you do that?
